description:
Metarhizium anisopliae is a species of entomopathogenic fungus, meaning it is a fungus that infects and kills insects. It is a naturally occurring soil-borne fungus that is widely distributed around the world.

Metarhizium anisopliae is a filamentous ascomycete fungus that produces green spores (conidia) on the surface of infected insects. The fungus can infect a wide range of insect pests, including beetles, grasshoppers, locusts, termites, and other agricultural and urban pests.

The fungus infects the host insect by adhering to the cuticle, germinating, and penetrating the insect's body. Once inside, the fungus proliferates, producing toxins and enzymes that ultimately kill the host. The fungus then emerges from the dead insect and produces more spores, which can then infect other insects.

Metarhizium anisopliae has been studied extensively as a biological control agent for various insect pests in agricultural and urban settings. Its ability to naturally infect and kill insects without harming humans or the environment has made it a promising alternative to chemical pesticides.
